title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) testing in the context of viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect antibodies generated by the immune system

options.label: B
options.text: To diagnose someone who is currently infected with a virus

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a vaccine for a new virus

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in detecting a virus's genetic material in the body, and how does PCR address this issue?

options.label: A
options.text: The genetic material is too abundant, and PCR reduces it

options.label: B
options.text: The genetic material is present in small amounts, and PCR amplifies it

options.label: C
options.text: The genetic material is too complex, and PCR simplifies it

options.label: D
options.text: The genetic material is too fragile, and PCR stabilizes it

multiple-choice.question: What is the first step in developing a PCR test for a new virus?

options.label: A
options.text: Collecting a sample from an infected individual

options.label: B
options.text: Sequencing the virus's genetic material or genome

options.label: C
options.text: Identifying the symptoms of the virus

options.label: D
options.text: Developing a vaccine for the virus

multiple-choice.question: What type of genetic information is encoded by the SARS-CoV-2 virus?
What is the purpose of reverse transcription in the PCR process for RNA viruses?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert the viral RNA into complementary DNA

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of immunoassays in the context of viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To diagnose someone who is currently infected with a virus

options.label: B
options.text: To detect antibodies generated by the immune system in response to a previous infection

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the genetic material of a virus in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a vaccine for a new virus

multiple-choice.question: What type of antibodies are typically detected by immunoassays to indicate a recent infection?
What is the significance of IgG antibodies in the context of immunoassays?

options.label: C
options.text: They indicate that someone was exposed to the virus and recovered

options.label: D
options.text: They indicate that someone was never exposed to the virus

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential use of blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: As a treatment for people who are currently fighting the virus

options.label: B
options.text: As a vaccine for people who are at risk of infection

options.label: C
options.text: As a diagnostic tool for detecting the virus

options.label: D
options.text: As a research tool for studying the virus

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of using digital PCR in the context of viral testing?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the accuracy of test results

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the time required for testing

options.label: C
options.text: It quantifies individual pieces of target DNA

options.label: D
options.text: It eliminates the need for PCR testing

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: What is a common trait among the world's scariest viruses such as Nipah, Hendra, Ebola, Marburg, and SARS?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all carried by birds.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all carried by bats.

options.label: C
options.text: They are all carried by pigs.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all carried by humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is a likely reason for the recent rise in outbreaks of these viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats are becoming more aggressive towards humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Humans and their animals are encroaching on bats' territory.

options.label: C
options.text: The viruses are becoming more contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: The bats are developing a stronger immune system.

options.text: The spread of commercial pig farms into bat-inhabited forests.

multiple-choice.question: Why do bats appear to carry more human-killing diseases than other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats are more susceptible to viruses.

options.label: B
options.text: Bats have a weaker immune system.

options.label: C
options.text: Bats often roost together in large numbers, allowing viruses to spread easily.

options.label: D
options.text: Bats are more aggressive towards humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique characteristic of infected bats?

options.label: A
options.text: They usually die quickly from the infection.

options.label: B
options.text: They live normal lives and can spread the virus to other bats.

options.label: C
options.text: They become more aggressive towards humans.

options.label: D
options.text: They develop a stronger immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What may be the reason bats are resilient to infection?
How do bats' internal temperatures change when they fly?
What is a result of some viruses evolving to tolerate the heat inside flying bats?

options.label: C
options.text: They can weather a human fever.

multiple-choice.question: Why are bats important to the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a food source for other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide insect control and pollination.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a source of disease.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a nuisance to humans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the coronavirus that causes the disease COVID-19?

options.label: A
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person's skin

options.label: B
options.text: Through droplets containing the virus that are sprayed out when an infected person coughs

multiple-choice.question: What type of viruses tend to be smaller, with fewer genes, and replicate quickly in their hosts?
Why do RNA viruses tend to have a higher mutation rate than DNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a proofreading mechanism that introduces errors

options.label: B
options.text: Because they do not have a proofreading mechanism to correct errors

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a larger genome that is more prone to errors

options.label: D
options.text: Because they replicate more slowly than DNA viruses

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about coronaviruses compared to other RNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: They are smaller and have fewer genes

options.label: B
options.text: They have a proofreading mechanism to correct errors

options.label: C
options.text: They have a faster mutation rate

options.label: D
options.text: They only infect animals, not humans

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the influenza virus mutates so quickly that new strains pop up constantly

options.label: B
options.text: Because the influenza virus is a DNA virus that is highly stable

options.label: C
options.text: Because the influenza virus only infects animals, not humans

options.label: D
options.text: Because the influenza virus is not highly contagious

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential advantage of the slower mutation rate of coronaviruses?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them more difficult to recognize and fight off

options.label: B
options.text: It makes antiviral drugs and vaccines less effective

options.label: C
options.text: It means our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines might be able to recognize them for longer after infection

options.label: D
options.text: It makes them more contagious and easily spread

multiple-choice.question: Why have there been no approved treatments or vaccines for coronaviruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because scientists have not been able to develop effective treatments or vaccines

options.label: B
options.text: Because the epidemics ended before treatments completed clinical trials

options.label: C
options.text: Because coronaviruses are not highly contagious or deadly

options.label: D
options.text: Because there is no need for treatments or vaccines for coronaviruses

options.text: Because hair is cut too slowly

title: Why is my leg asleep?

multiple-choice.question: What is the common term for the tingling, prickly feeling you get when your arm or leg "wakes up" after being numb?
Why do people call an arm or leg "asleep" when it becomes numb?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not getting enough blood

options.label: C
options.text: Because you can't feel much with it while it's numb

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the blood vessels when you sit in one position or lean on your arm or leg for a while?
Why do nerves only work well if they're getting enough blood?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they need oxygen to function

options.label: B
options.text: Because they need energy to send signals

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need nutrients to stay healthy

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: By leaning on your arm or leg for a while

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to help the blood get flowing again when you get pins and needles?

options.label: B
